conclusion: To determine when objects A and B are farthest apart, we need to analyze their positions over time based on their velocity-time (v-t) graphs.
Object A moves with a constant velocity, as indicated by the straight line.
Object B initially slows down, reaches a minimum velocity, and then speeds up, as shown by the curved line.
The distance traveled by each object can be found by calculating the area under each curve from time \( t = 0 \) to any given time \( t \).

premise: The position of each object at any time \( t \) is the integral of its velocity from \( 0 \) to \( t \).
conclusion: The position of each object is the area under the velocity-time graph.

premise: The separation between the two objects is the difference in the areas under their respective curves.
conclusion: The separation is determined by the difference in areas under the curves.
At \( t_1 \), Object B reaches its minimum velocity.
At \( t_2 \), the velocities of A and B are equal.

premise: From \( 0 \) to \( t_1 \), Object A is moving faster than Object B.
conclusion: Object A is ahead of Object B from \( 0 \) to \( t_1 \).

premise: From \( t_1 \) to \( t_2 \), Object B accelerates and eventually matches the velocity of A at \( t_2 \).
conclusion: Object B catches up to Object A by \( t_2 \).

premise: The maximum separation occurs when the difference in the areas under the curves is the greatest.
conclusion: The maximum separation occurs just before \( t_2 \).

premise: This happens just before \( t_2 \), as after \( t_2 \), Object B starts to catch up to Object A.
conclusion: The two objects are farthest apart at time \( t_1 \).
